content:
Modification of authorities regarding the use of pen registers and trap and trace devices. The amendment to Section 3121(c) of title 18, United States Code expands the use of pen registers and trap and trace devices by governmental agencies. It includes changes to the processing and transmitting of wire and electronic communications. Additionally, the amendment allows for the issuance of ex parte orders for the installation and use of these devices upon application by the Government attorney. The court can authorize the installation and use of pen registers or trap and trace devices for ongoing criminal investigations. The order applies to any entity providing communication services in the US. The court can authorize the installation and use of pen registers or trap and trace devices for ongoing criminal investigations. The order applies to any entity providing communication services in the US. The amendment includes inserting "or other facility" after "telephone line" and providing a description of the communications to which the order applies, including identifiers and geographic limits. The amendment expands the scope of the court order to include any facility providing communication services, with specific details on identifiers and geographic limits. Additionally, it allows for emergency installations in cases of national security threats or public health and safety concerns. The amendment broadens court order scope to cover communication service facilities, with emergency installations allowed for national security threats or public health and safety concerns. Definitions are updated for court jurisdiction and pen register. The amendment broadens court order scope to cover communication service facilities, with emergency installations allowed for national security threats or public health and safety concerns. Definitions are updated for court jurisdiction and pen register. The text is amended to include dialing, routing, addressing, or signalling information transmitted by an instrument or facility from which a wire or electronic communication is transmitted, and to insert "or process" after "device" each place it appears. The trap and trace device paragraph is also amended to include "or process" after "a device" and to update information relevant to identifying the source of communication. The amendment updates definitions for court jurisdiction and pen register, broadens court order scope to cover communication service facilities, and includes information relevant to identifying the source of communication. SEC. 2. MODIFICATION OF PROVISIONS RELATING TO FRAUD AND RELATED ACTIVITY IN CONNECTION WITH COMPUTERS. Penalties under section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to include exceptions in subparagraphs (B) and (C) and modify offenses punishable under subsection (a)(2). Penalties under section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to include exceptions in subparagraph (C) for offenses causing loss over $5,000 or medical harm. The amendments to penalties under section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, include exceptions for offenses causing loss over $5,000 or medical harm, physical injury, threats to public health or safety, and damage to government computer systems related to justice, defense, or security. The amendments to section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, include defining the term 'damage' as impairment to data, program, system, or information. It also expands the definition of 'conviction' to include juvenile delinquency for violations of this section. The amendments to section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, include defining 'loss' as any reasonable cost to a victim, and limiting damages in civil actions to loss unless specific elements are present. Additionally, criminal forfeiture consequences are imposed on individuals convicted of offenses under this section. The court may order a person convicted of a violation to forfeit property used in the crime or obtained from it to the United States. The forfeiture process is governed by the Controlled Substances Act. The court may order forfeiture of property used in or obtained from a crime to the United States under subsection (d). Subsection (e) further expands on civil forfeiture, allowing seizure of property used to commit a violation or derived from illegal activities. Chapter 46 of the title applies to civil forfeiture under this subsection. SEC. 3. JUVENILE DELINQUENCY.

Amends section 5032 of title 18, United States Code to include additional felony violations related to juvenile delinquency.

SEC. 4. AMENDMENT TO SENTENCING GUIDELINES.

Amends section 805(c) of the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 to specify felony violations for sentencing guidelines. SEC. 5. DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE GRANTS TO IMPROVE DOMESTIC PREPAREDNESS TO COMBAT TERRORISM. The Secretary of Defense may authorize research and development grants for the prevention of cyberterrorism and the development of technology products or services for this purpose. Recipients of grants must submit a report on their research or development results and provide the Secretary with the technologies and processes used. The Secretary of Defense may provide grants to entities to improve their critical information protection architecture or refinance previous improvements. Recipients must report on the results of the improvements made. The Secretary of Defense may provide grants or contracts for improving critical information protection. Regulations will be followed, including goals for assistance use and evaluation standards. Definitions include cyberterrorism acts on protected computers. The Secretary of Defense may provide grants or contracts for improving critical information protection, including cyberterrorism prevention. Qualified entities or organizations must meet prevention standards and respond efficiently to cyberterrorism. A report must be submitted within 30 days after the specified period. The Secretary of Defense will submit a report to Congress on activities conducted under this section within 30 days after the specified period. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001 for these activities.
